text:
<!channel> Hello :blush: I figured it’s high time to get around to completing my own challenges, so here goes my question to you all:
The conversation I got into in my second breakout room discussion revolved around differences between subdisciplines of psychology in terms of what open science practices are already used/expected or absolute no-goes. This made me curious: what are some of the open science practices that are already prevalent in your research community? What practices seem completely out of the question?

elements.text:
I figured it’s high time to get around to completing my own challenges, so here goes my question to you all:
The conversation I got into in my second breakout room discussion revolved around differences between subdisciplines of psychology in terms of what open science practices are already used/expected or absolute no-goes. This made me curious: what are some of the open science practices that are already prevalent in your research community? What practices seem completely out of the question?

text: My impression of human neuroimaging research is that preregistration is one of the big things that there is much resistance to. I don’t know if this is the main reason, but there are so many ways to preprocess and analyze data, and which ones you use matter for the results you find (which is a lot less talked about than it should). I get that it’s difficult to know before you collect data how exactly you should go about all this as unexpected artifacts and issues might come up along the way, but the idea that ‘preregistration can’t be done’ in neuroimaging just makes me feel that what we are doing is kinda shady..

elements.text: My impression of human neuroimaging research is that preregistration is one of the big things that there is much resistance to. I don’t know if this is the main reason, but there are so many ways to preprocess and analyze data, and which ones you use matter for the results you find (which is a lot less talked about than it should). I get that it’s difficult to know before you collect data how exactly you should go about all this as unexpected artifacts and issues might come up along the way, but the idea that ‘preregistration can’t be done’ in neuroimaging just makes me feel that what we are doing is kinda shady..

text:
Great question! :smile: Open data actually seems well-supported with human neuroimaging (e.g., human connectome project, studyforrest, etc.), although I don’t know if this holds true as much for individual researchers/studies. Open code and software also seem pretty normal.

I think your point on preregistration is good <@U01AA7U2ECA>, especially since a lot of research in the area is exploratory, so there’s even less pressure to preregister and studies can be a bit more liberal with researcher degrees of freedom there. But even in exploratory research I think there can be room to preregister certain aspects of the study

I think your point on preregistration is good

, especially since a lot of research in the area is exploratory, so there’s even less pressure to preregister and studies can be a bit more liberal with researcher degrees of freedom there. But even in exploratory research I think there can be room to preregister certain aspects of the study

text: When I did child research, I’m not sure if open data was actively being promoted. My data was to be sent to a larger database that people needed permission to use. with behavioural cognitive stuff it can be difficult to use some data when different groups used different editions of the same assessment (particularly for longitudinal developmental work).

elements.text: When I did child research, I’m not sure if open data was actively being promoted. My data was to be sent to a larger database that people needed permission to use. with behavioural cognitive stuff it can be difficult to use some data when different groups used different editions of the same assessment (particularly for longitudinal developmental work).

text: Yeah I think for open data, there are some amazing databases for neuroimaging, but outside of those kinds of specific projects, data sharing is very limited, and if it’s shared, it’s often not in its raw form.. Same goes for code in my experience, there are some amazing projects and software packages available, but the articles I read rarely share their specific code.. (I do have one positive experience of asking a random researcher for their code and getting it, with some explanations! :blush:)
